original_title: Sri Lanka sees deflation of 1.7-pct by Dec 2024
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Consumer Prices fell 1.7 percent in the year to December 2024, the fifth straight month where 12-month deflation was recorded, data from the state statistics office showed.s.
Sri Lanka’s central bank has operated broadly deflationary policy since September 2022 allowing it to collect foreign reserves and also appreciate the exchange rate.
Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe is credited with preventing possible hyperinflation and laying stable monetary foundation for growth.

However there have been warnings that the central bank printing money in the last quarter of the year, in a bid to push down interest rates, at a time when markets were already flushed with liquidity.
By the beginning of December excess liquidity was up to 246 billion rupees with about 30 billion rupees being printed overnight and more money on term deals.
The central bank was at one time injecting as much as 100 billion rupees through overnight and term operations.

Sri Lanka also started a single policy rate, which analysts said is also incompatible with stability in a reserve collecting central bank and will have the same effects as mid-corridor rate targeting with excess liquidity from 2015.

Analysts warned that the central bank will eventually lose its ability to collect reserves, when credit growth picked up, if inflationary open market operations continued and the country will default again or social unrest wills start as food and energy prices start to go up as most people are living on the edge.
The central bank has persuaded the political leadership to push up cost of living by 5 to 7 percent a year.

Macro-economists believe that inflation – or price pressure – is needed to drive economic growth, but the inflation has led to currency crises and large part of the workforce is seeking employment in currency board like regimes in the Middle East.
There is also legal and illegal migration to low inflation floating rate regimes with greater monetary stability. (Colombo/Dec31/2024)
